conclusion: A shadow lies on the continuation of the straight line that joins the light-source to every point of the object.
If the lamp is moved while the object stays still, each of those straight lines swings round, so the footprint of the shadow both shifts its position on the floor and changes its size/shape.
Forward means toward the viewer (toward the lower edge of the picture).
Above means the lamp is now higher above the ground than it was before.
The lamp goes from a low, rearward position to a higher, forward-overhead position.
Every shadow center slides in the opposite direction to the lamp’s motion, i.e., backward in the picture (away from the viewer, toward the top of the frame).
The taller the object, the farther its shadow moves.
Vertical rays become steeper, so the horizontal reach of every ray becomes shorter.
Each shadow shrinks (its longest dimension gets smaller), and its outline becomes more compact and less elongated.
A taller object still casts a slightly larger patch than a shorter one, but all of them are reduced compared with the original.
Object height order (largest first) is approximately B (alarm clock) > A (bowl) > C (berry tart) > D (waffle).
A (bowl): shadow slides a moderate distance toward the top of the frame and becomes noticeably smaller and rounder.
B (alarm clock): slides the farthest of the four and remains the biggest, but its footprint still contracts markedly.
C (berry tart): shifts a little less than A, ends up nearly under the tart, and contracts to a small, almost circular spot.
D (waffle): moves the least (waffle is very low), ending practically under its own edges; becomes the smallest of all.

When the lamp is pushed forward and raised, every shadow A-D retreats in the opposite direction (toward the picture’s top) while simultaneously shrinking; the higher the object, the farther its shadow travels and the larger the remnant patch, but all four shadows end up closer to their respective objects and appreciably smaller than before.
